facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 46 of 1969 filed in Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 46, of 1969.

facts.text: Appeal under Article 134(1)(c) of the Constitution from Patna High Court judgment dated December 10, 1968 in Criminal Appeal No. 116 of 1966

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Article 134 1  c  of the Constitution of India from the judgment and order dated December 10, 1968, of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 116 of 1966.

facts.text: Appellant Jugal Kishore and five others from village Mandil in District Gaya tried by Additional Sessions Judge Gaya

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and five others, who belong to village Mandil in District Gaya, were tried in the companyrt of Additional Sessions Judge Gaya for offences under sections 147, 148, 307, 323 and 307 read with section 149 Indian Penal Code and section 25 of the Arms Act.

facts.text: Jugal Kishore convicted under section 326 read with section 149 IPC and sentenced to 5 years rigorous imprisonment, and under section 148 IPC to 2 years rigorous imprisonment, to run concurrently

anchor.surface_text: Jugal Kishore appellant was companyvicted under section 326 read with section 149 and section 148 Indian Penal Code and was sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for a period of five years on the first companynt and rigorous imprisonment for a, period of two years on the second companynt. The sentences awarded to the appellant were ordered to run companycurrently.

facts.text: Patna High Court by judgment dated January 22, 1968 acquitted two accused, maintained appellant's conviction under 326/149 and 148 IPC, reduced sentence for 326/149 to 3 years RI, maintained 2 years for 148 IPC

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Patna High Court as per judgment dated January 22, 1968 acquitted two of the accused. The companyviction of the appellant for offences under section 326 read with section 149 and 148 Indian Penal Code was maintained. The sentence of the appellant for the offence under section 326 read with section 149 Indian Penal Code was reduced from five years to three years. The sentence for the offence under section 148 Indian Penal Code was, however, maintained.

facts.text: High Court rejected appellant's application for Probation of Offenders Act on December 12, 1968 as offence punishable with life imprisonment

anchor.surface_text: This application was rejected by the High Court as per ,order dated December 12, 1968 on the ground that the offence for which the appellant had been companyvicted was punishable with imprisonment for life, and as such, the provisions of Probation of Offenders Act companyld numberbe invoked in his case.

facts.text: Incident occurred on October 14, 1964 at about 10 a.m.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and his companypanions were tried on the allegation that on October 14, 1964 at about 10 a.m.,

facts.text: Madho Saran was getting his field bearing No. 1678 ploughed by Rakshya Mahto

anchor.surface_text: while Madho Saran was getting his field bearing No. 1678 ploughed by his ploughman Rakshya Mahto, the appellant and Raghu accused went there and questioned Madho Saran for cutting the ridge between field No. 1678 and 1719.

facts.text: Appellant questioned Madho Saran for cutting ridge between field No. 1678 and 1719, which belonged to appellant

anchor.surface_text: the appellant and Raghu accused went there and questioned Madho Saran for cutting the ridge between field No. 1678 and 1719. Field No. 1719 belonged to the appellant.

facts.text: Madho Saran narrated incident to brother Sadho Saran, they along with others came out and met accused accompanied by about 30 persons near a barrage

anchor.surface_text: Madho Saran went to his house and narrated the incident to his brother Sadho Saran. Madho Saran and Sadho Saran along with others then came out of their house and while they were near a barrage, they met the accused who were accompanied by about 30 person of their village.

facts.text: Hira Lal, armed with gun, fired a shot hitting Sadho Saran on his head

anchor.surface_text: One of the accused, namely, Hira Lal, who was armed with a gun, fired a shot as a result of which Sadho Saran was hit on his head.

facts.text: Sadho Saran fell down, other accused including appellant armed with garasa caused further injuries to Sadho Saran and companions with sharp-edged and blunt weapons

anchor.surface_text: Sadho Saran fell down, whereafter 87 7 the other accused, including the appellant who was armed with a garasa, caused further injuries to Sadho Saran and his companypanions with sharp-edged and blunt weapons.

facts.text: Injured taken to Jehanabad Hospital

anchor.surface_text: The injured were thereafter taken to Jehanabad Hospital.

facts.text: Police Sub Inspector recorded statement of Madho Saran at hospital on intimation from doctor

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of intimation from the doctor incharge of the hospital, a police Sub Inspector went to the hospital and recorded the statement of Madho Saran,

facts.text: Nand Kishore, one of the accused, lodged a report at the police station

anchor.surface_text: Nand Kishore, one of the accused, also lodged a report at the police station.

facts.text: Appellant stated his age as 19 years in statement under Section 342 CrPC, assumed less than 21 years at time of conviction by trial court

anchor.surface_text: The appellant gave. his age to be 19 years in his statement under Section 342 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, and the case has been argued before us on the assumption that the appellant was less than 21 years of age at the time of his companyviction by the Additional Sessions Judge.

facts.text: Appellant convicted for offence under section 326 read with section 149 IPC, punishable with imprisonment for life or up to 10 years and fine

anchor.surface_text: The main offence for which the appellant has been companyvicted is section 326 read with section 149 Indian Penal Code. Section 326 deals with the offence of voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means and the punishment prescribed for the offence is imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years. The companyvicted person shall also be liable to pay fine.

facts.text: High Court certified case fit for Supreme Court appeal involving question on applicability of Probation of Offenders Act

anchor.surface_text: On prayer made by the appellant, the High Court certified the case to be fit for appeal to the Supreme Court as it involved the question relating to the applicability of the Probation of Offenders Act.

facts.text: Other three accused convictions maintained by High Court with sentences of imprisonment

anchor.surface_text: The companyviction of the other three accused was maintained for some of the offences, and they were awarded sentences of imprisonment on that companynt.

facts.text: Appellant armed with a garasa during the incident

anchor.surface_text: including the appellant who was armed with a garasa,

issues.text: whether the appellant who was less than 21 years of age on the date of his conviction for an offence under section 326 read with section 149 Indian Penal Code, can claim the benefit of section 6 of the Probation of Offenders Act, 1958

anchor.surface_text: The short question which arises for determination in this appeal on certificate granted by Patna High Court is whether the appellant who was less than 21 years of age on the date of his conviction for an offence under section 326 read with section 149 Indian Penal Code, can claim the, benefit of section 6, of the Probation of Offenders Act,, 1958

issues.text: whether the appellant can claim the benefit of the Probation of Offenders Act

anchor.surface_text: The question with which we are concerned in this appeal, as mentioned earlier, is whether the appellant can claim the benefit of the Probation of Offenders Act.

issues.text: whether an offence punishable with imprisonment for life but also with lesser term of imprisonment is excluded from section 6 of the Probation of Offenders Act

anchor.surface_text: Plain reading of section 6 makes it manifest that it deals with persons under twenty-one years of age who are found guilty of having committed an offence punishable with imprisonment but not with imprisonment for life.

arguments.claim: The provisions of the Probation of Offenders Act could not be invoked because the offence for which the appellant had been convicted was punishable with imprisonment for life

anchor.surface_text: This application was rejected by the High Court as per ,order dated December 12, 1968 on the ground that the offence for which the appellant had been convicted was punishable with imprisonment for life, and as such, the provisions of Probation of Offenders Act could not be invoked in his case.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to be shown that the companyvicted person even though less than 21 years of age, is number guilty of an offence punishable with imprisonment for life

arguments.court_reasoning: Plain reading of section 6 excludes offences punishable with imprisonment for life even if lesser punishments are also possible

arguments.claim: The offence under section 326 read with section 149 IPC is punishable not only with imprisonment for life but also with imprisonment up to ten years, so the appellant can claim benefit of section 6 of the Probation of Offenders Act

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Misra on behalf of the appellant has urged that as the offence under section 326 read with section 149 Indian Penal Code is punishable not only with imprisonment for life but also with imprisonment which may extend up to ten years, the benefit of section 6 of the Act can be invoked by the appellant.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e shown that the companyvicted person even th

arguments.court_reasoning: This contention, in our opinion, is not well founded

arguments.claim: Plain reading of section 6 shows it applies to persons under 21 found guilty of offences punishable with imprisonment but not with imprisonment for life

anchor.surface_text: Plain reading of section 6 makes it manifest that it deals with persons under twenty-one years of age who are found guilty of having committed an offence punishable with imprisonment but not with imprisonment for life.

arguments.claim: To hold otherwise would ignore the words 'but not with imprisonment for life' making them otiose, which is not permissible

anchor.surface_text: To hold otherwise would have the effect of ignoring the words but not with imprisonment for life and treating them to be otiose. Such a construction is plainly not permissible.

arguments.claim: The section excludes offences punishable with imprisonment for life even if lesser term can also be awarded; language does not limit exclusion to offences punishable only with life and no lesser term

anchor.surface_text: We also cannot subscribe to the view that the offences excluded from the purview of the section are only those offences wherein punishment prescribed is imprisonment for life and not for a lesser term, for the language used in the section does not warrant such a view.

arguments.claim: The policy of the Act is to deny benefit in cases of very serious offences punishable with imprisonment for life

anchor.surface_text: The policy underlying the Act appears to be that it is only in cases of not very serious nature, viz., offences not punishable with imprisonment for life that the convicted person should have the benefit of provisions of the Act.

arguments.claim: In Som Nath Puri v. State of Rajasthan, conviction under section 409 IPC (punishable with life or up to 10 years) held ineligible for section 4 of Probation Act as punishable with life imprisonment

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Som Nath Puri v. State of Rajasthan the appellant had been convicted for an offence under section 409 Indian Penal Code. ... It was held by this Court that in such a case the provisions of section 4 of the Probation of Offenders Act cannot be invoked.

arguments.claim: Section 18 expressly excludes certain offences like under Prevention of Corruption Act from the Act

anchor.surface_text: Likewise, there are certain offences like those under the Prevention of Corruption Act wherein the convicted person cannot claim the protection of the Act. Section 18 of the Act expressly excludes such offences from the purview of the Act.

holdings.text: This contention, in our opinion, is not well founded.

anchor.surface_text: This contention, in our opinion, is not well founded. Plain reading of section 6 makes it manifest that it deals with persons under twenty-one years of age who are found guilty of having committed an offence punishable with imprisonment but not with imprisonment for life.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's argument that benefit available since lesser punishment also possible rejected based on plain language of section 6 excluding offences punishable with life imprisonment

holdings.text: Plain reading of section 6 makes it manifest that it deals with persons under twenty-one years of age who are found guilty of having committed an offence punishable with imprisonment but not with imprisonment for life.

anchor.surface_text: Plain reading of section 6 makes it manifest that it deals with persons under twenty-one years of age who are found guilty of having committed an offence punishable with imprisonment but not with imprisonment for life.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of section 6 limits its application to offences not punishable with life imprisonment

holdings.text: As imprisonment for life can also be awarded for the offence under section 326 read with section 149 Indian Penal Code, a person found guilty of such an offence would not be entitled to claim the benefit of section 6.

anchor.surface_text: As imprisonment for life can also be awarded for the offence under section 326 read with section 149 Indian Penal Code, a person found guilty of such an offence would not be entitled to claim the benefit of section 6. To hold otherwise would have the effect of ignoring the words but not with imprisonment for life

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of section 6 to specific offence under 326/149 IPC which carries life imprisonment excludes benefit

holdings.text: To hold otherwise would have the effect of ignoring the words but not with imprisonment for life and treating them to be otiose. Such a construction is plainly not permissible.

anchor.surface_text: To hold otherwise would have the effect of ignoring the words but not with imprisonment for life and treating them to be otiose. Such a construction is plainly not permissible. We also cannot subscribe to the view that the offences excluded from the purview of the section

holdings.reasoning_summary: Alternative interpretation would render key statutory words surplusage, violating rules of construction

holdings.text: We also cannot subscribe to the view that the offences excluded from the purview of the section are only those offences wherein punishment prescribed is imprisonment for life and not for a lesser term, for the language used in the section does not warrant such a view.

anchor.surface_text: We also cannot subscribe to the view that the offences excluded from the purview of the section are only those offences wherein punishment prescribed is imprisonment for life and not for a lesser term, for the language used in the section does not warrant such a view. On the contrary, the plain meaning of the section is that the section cannot be invoked by a person who is convicted for an offence punishable with imprisonment for life.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language does not support limiting exclusion only to offences solely punishable by life without lesser options

holdings.text: The policy underlying the Act appears to be that it is only in cases of not very serious nature, viz., offences not punishable with imprisonment for life that the convicted person should have the benefit of provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The policy underlying the Act appears to be that it is only in cases of not very serious nature, viz., offences not punishable with imprisonment for life that the convicted person should have the benefit of provisions of the Act. Where, however, the offence for which a person has been convicted is of a serious nature punishable with imprisonment for life, the benefit of the Act would not be permissible in his case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative purpose restricts probation benefits to less serious offences not carrying life imprisonment

holdings.text: It was held by this Court that in such a case the provisions of section 4 of the Probation of Offenders Act cannot be invoked.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of Som Nath Puri v. State of Rajasthan the appellant had been convicted for an offence under section 409 Indian Penal Code. Punishment for the offence under section 409 Indian Penal Code is the same as for the offence under section 326, namely, imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years and the liability to pay fine. It was held by this Court that in such a case the provisions of section 4 of the Probation of Offenders Act cannot be invoked.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous precedent under similar provision (section 4 for section 409 IPC) confirms exclusion for life-punishable offences

precedents.citation: Som Nath Puri v. State of Rajasthan  1

anchor.surface_text: Som Nath Puri v. State of Rajasthan  1

precedents.case_name: Som Nath Puri v. State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: provisions of section 4 of the Probation of Offenders Act cannot be invoked in case of conviction for an offence punishable with imprisonment for life, such as section 409 Indian Penal Code
precedents.cited_holding: As the offence of criminal breach of trust under section 409, I.P.C. is punishable with imprisonment for life, the High Court, in our view, was right because the provisions of section 4 are only applicable to a case of a person found guilty of having companym itted an offence number punishable with death or imprisonment for life.

anchor.surface_text: We also cannot subscribe to the view that the offences excluded from the purview of the section are only those offences wherein punishment prescribed is imprisonment for life and not for a lesser term, for the language used in the section does not warrant such a view. On the contrary, the plain meaning of the section is that the section cannot be invoked by a person who is convicted for an offence punishable with imprisonment for life.

We also cannot subscribe to the view that the offences excluded from the purview of the section are only those offences wherein punishment prescribed is imprisonment for life and not for a lesser term, for the language used in the section does not warrant such a view. On the contrary, the plain meaning of the section is that the section cannot be invoked by a person who is convicted for an offence punishable with imprisonment for life.

anchor.surface_text: The policy underlying the Act appears to be that it is only in cases of not very serious nature, viz., offences not punishable with imprisonment for life that the convicted person should have the benefit of provisions of the Act. Where, however, the offence for which a person has been convicted is of a serious nature punishable with imprisonment for life, the benefit of the Act would not be permissible in his case.

anchor.surface_text: The policy underlying the Act appears to be that it is only in cases of not very serious nature, viz., offences not punishable with imprisonment for life that the convicted person should have the benefit of provisions of the Act. Where, however, the offence for which a person has been convicted is of a serious nature punishable with imprisonment for life, the benefit of the Act would not be permissible in his case.

In the case of Som Nath Puri v. State of Rajasthan the appellant had been convicted for an offence under section 409 Indian Penal Code. Punishment for the offence under section 409 Indian Penal Code is the same as for the offence under section 326, namely, imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years and the liability to pay fine. It was held by this Court that in such a case the provisions of section 4 of the Probation of Offenders Act cannot be invoked.
